qas.question: What caused the energy efficiency to go up?
Elimination of what helped the efficiency of diesel traction to go up?
What type of locomotives got improved during 1950-1973 in Soviet Union?
How much of energy was saved and re-used due to regenerative braking in 1989?
Was there an energy efficiency improvement in the period 1974 through 1980?
There was a decreased use of what type of braking?
The overall efficiency of electric traction tripled during what years?
The overall efficiency of electric traction tripled in what country?
There were massive improvements in energy-intensity after what year?
Energy-efficiency increases as what goes up?

context: Besides increased efficiency of power plants, there was an increase in efficiency (between 1950 and 1973) of the railway utilization of this electricity with <a0_0>energy-intensity dropping<a0_0/> from 218 to 124 kwh/10,000 gross tonne-km (of both passenger and freight trains) or a 43% drop. Since energy-intensity is the inverse of energy-efficiency it drops as <b9_0>efficiency<b9_0/> goes up. But most of this 43% decrease in energy-intensity also benefited diesel traction. The conversion of wheel bearings from plain to roller, increase of train weight, converting single track lines to double track (or partially double track), and the elimination of obsolete <a1_0>2-axle freight cars<a1_0/> increased the energy-efficiency of all types of traction: <a2_0>electric<a2_0/>, diesel, and steam. However, there remained a 12–15% reduction of energy-intensity that only benefited electric traction (and not diesel). This was due to improvements in locomotives, more widespread use of <b5_0>regenerative<b5_0/> braking (which in 1989 recycled <a3_0>2.65%<a3_0/> of the electric energy used for traction,) remote control of substations, better handling of the locomotive by the locomotive crew, and improvements in automation. Thus the overall efficiency of electric traction as compared to diesel more than doubled between <b6_0>1950 and the mid-1970s<b6_0/> in <b7_0>the Soviet Union<b7_0/>. But after <b8_0>1974<b8_0/> (thru 1980) there was <a4_0>no improvement<a4_0/> in energy-intensity (wh/tonne-km) in part due to increasing speeds of passenger and freight trains.
